Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Andres Felipe Osorio of University of California, Berkeley to conduct a research project in ENG during the summer of 2013 at Hokkaido University in Sapporo, Japan. The project title is "Material Flammability in Microgravity Environments." The host scientist is Professor Osamu Fujita.

Fires in spacecrafts are dangerous scenarios given the confined space and the risk for astronauts onboard. Understanding the effect of microgravity in fires is an important step towards developing a better knowledge of fire prevention and mitigation in space. This project develops a better understanding of how microgravity conditions affect the flammability of materials when compared to normal gravity.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, this project will help developing content in the form of pictures, videos, presentations, etc. that can be used to showcase that space-funded research is not only relevant to space agencies but something the general public can relate to.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A fire inside a spacecraft represents an extremely dangerous situation because unlike a fire on earth, an evacuation is difficult. As of now the best way to avoid fires in space is to use materials that are not likely to burn in environments similar to those found in a spacecraft. Determining whether or not a material is likely to burn in space is challenging, especially because the absence of gravity not only changes how flames look in space, but makes materials more susceptible to catch on fire. Electrical cables and harnesses have been identified as a possible source of fires in a spacecraft and their combustion in the absence of gravity has received much attention. The great majority of electrical cables microgravity fire research has used Polyethylene (PE) insulated cables because its combustion in normal gravity conditions has been extensively studied and is well understood. However, PE insulated wires burn in normal room conditions, making them a less than ideal candidate for use in space. In actual space application materials such as ETFE and PTFE are used as insulation of electrical cables. Still, their flammability in space conditions remains largely unknown.

The focus of this project is to investigate the flammability of ETFE insulated cables in both normal gravity (1g) and microgravity (μg) conditions. ETFE is a fire resistant material in normal room conditions; however, there is a possibility that changes in gravity and other environment variables can make ETFE flammable. One of those environmental variables is radiant heat, such in the case of a nearby fire. In this work, experiments with ETFE insulated electrical cables exposed to different levels of radiant heat and oxygen concentration are used to determine flammability boundaries in terms of radiant heat, oxygen concentration, and gravity conditions.

Results show that the combination of μg conditions and addition of a radiant heat source are able to extend the range of oxygen concentrations over which ETFE insulted cables are flammable. Moreover, it was found that addition of a radiant heat in combination with μg conditions could make ETFE cables flammable in normal air (21% Oxygen). From the experiments it was noted that changes in flame shape and the manner in which heat is transferred from the flame to the cable insulation change significantly from 1g to μg. Figure 1 shows an ETFE insulated wire exposed to radiant heat burning in μg conditions and Figure 2. shows the flame once gravity increases to normal conditions (1g). Notice how flame length, height and brightness change from μg to 1g.

In addition, the results obtained using ETFE insulated cables were compared to previous results obtained using PE as the insulation material. This comparison showed that microgravity has a more pronounced effect on ETFE than in PE. In the experiments conducted ETFE required an oxygen concentration of 32% to burn in 1g, and 26% μg. In comparison, PE required 19% in 1g and 16% in μg. The fact that microgravity results in a bigger decrease in ETFE highlights the importance of studying the flammability of materials used in space applications because despite being fire resistant in normal gravity, the same material may be flammable in spacecraft environments.

This project not only benefits the fire safety and space community, but it also brings awareness to research conducted in space. This can be used as a educational resource for explaining what kind of research is conducted in space and how its applications are not only limited to space applications. For example, although this research studies combustion in microgravity, the fundamental knowledge obtained in this research enhances our understanding of fire, and can increase our understanding of the benefits, risks and effectivness of fire retardants in consumer products.
